definition: to lose sth abstract but important (courage, authority, one's life etc)/to be bereaved of (one's spouse etc)/to die/disappointed/discouraged
clock/o'clock/time as measured in hours and minutes/bell/CL:架[jia4],座[zuo4]

sentences.english: Knell beetles have also been known to be used as mounts by Underdark races.
sentences.chinese: 已經知道喪鐘甲蟲會被幽暗地域的種族用作坐騎。

sentences.english: It was tolling for the funeral service.
sentences.chinese: 這是宣佈葬禮開始的喪鐘。

sentences.english: It sounded the death knell of all her hopes.
sentences.chinese: 那事聽起來就像是給她的一切希望敲起了喪鐘。

sentences.english: Knell beetles were used as mounts by the warrior legions of the ancient Dhakaan Empire.
sentences.chinese: 喪鐘甲蟲被古代達卡安帝國的武士軍團作爲坐騎使用。

sentences.english: Now I hear them --- Ding-dong, bell.
sentences.chinese: 我現在聽到了叮咚的喪鐘。

sentences.english: And four days afterwards the bells toll for a funeral in the convent of Borglum.
sentences.chinese: 聖誕節後第三天晚上，伯爾厄隆修道院敲響了喪鐘。

sentences.english: A diplomatic crisis would sound the death knell of any hopes of disarmament.
sentences.chinese: 外交上的危機將爲任何裁軍希望敲響喪鐘。

sentences.english: And the funeral bells surely tolled this week when General Motors filed for bankruptcy.
sentences.chinese: 本週當通用汽車公司破產時，喪鐘必將敲響。

sentences.english: Change is our life-blood, stagnation our death knell.
sentences.chinese: 改變是我們的生命血脈，停滯則如同敲起喪鐘。

sentences.english: "This court settlement signals the death knell for mercury fillings, " Brown predicted.
sentences.chinese: 這個庭外和解敲響了汞填充物的喪鐘。

sentences.english: And the undertaker starts to ring my funeral bell.
sentences.chinese: 當送葬者開始搖響我葬禮的喪鐘。

sentences.english: At that moment all the church bells in Palermo began to ring for Vespers .
sentences.chinese: 那一刻所有教堂的鐘聲在巴勒莫開始響喪鐘。

sentences.english: Who'll toll the bell? "I, " said the bull.
That kind of post is a death knell for a blog.
sentences.chinese: 這樣的帖子就像給博客敲喪鐘。

definition: to turn a deaf ear to (idiom); to pretend not to hear
to die without a burial site/to die a pauper/a tragic end
pinyin: si3 wu2 zang4 shen1 zhi1 di4

definition: to whisper to one another's ear
lit. like a sheet of loose sand/fig. unable to cooperate (idiom)
lit. wind and rain darken the sky (idiom); fig. the situation looks grim
no room to advance or to retreat (idiom); at a loss/in a hopeless situation
lit. to kill the chicken to get the eggs (idiom)/fig. to kill the goose that lays the golden eggs
to make an effort to become strong (idiom); determined to do better/to pull one's socks up
